com.tsgrp.migration.util

Class TokenUtil

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.tsgrp.migration.util.TokenUtil

  • public class TokenUtil
extends java.lang.Object
    A utility class for converting a string with tokens such as @{object_name} with attribute values from a Node. The fun doesn't end there- tokens can contain such elegant constructs as "arguments" and "values" and even scary "Transformers". This is without a doubt the best token parser and replacer you will see on the 5th floor of a particularly short Chicago building.

    The following is a quick rundown on the supported tokens and how they are processed.

    Plain single attribute: @{om_name}
    The token is replaced with the attribute value off the node, or "" (blank) if not available.
    Plain repeating attribute: @{keywords}
    The token is replaced with a comma-separated dump of the attributes, such as "foo,bar,baz".
    *
    Plain repeating attribute with specified delimiter: @{keywords:delimiter=&}
    The token is replaced with a comma-separated dump of the attributes using the given delimiter, such as "foo&bar&baz". Any sequence of characters can be used. If a colon (':') is desired, it must be escaped using '\:'.
    Special attribute: @{omx_current_date}
    This is an attribute that doesn't really exist on the node, but the token parser is responsible for handling. Currently the following are available:
    • omx_current_date - replaced with the current date in the default format
    Attribute with index/delimiter arguments: @{om_folder:index=1:delimiter=/}
    If an attribute such as a folder path ("test/folder/path") needs to be split into its parts so only portions is used, this is the thing to do the job. The above example with the mentioned string will return "folder".
    Attribute with date format: @{omx_current_date:pattern=yyyy}
    Any attribute recognized as a date can be supplied a pattern which is passed to a SimpleDateFormat object for processing. This example will return the current year, e.g. "2081".
    Attribute with multiple arguments: @{repeating_date:pattern=yyyy:delimiter=/}
    This will apply both the date formatting processor and delimit the repeating attribute values with the '/' character.
    Transformers @{MockTransformer~information}
    TODO

    NOTE:Ensure that any literal colon character (':') you wish to use inside an argument value is escaped using '\:'. If not, it will be interpreted incorrectly.

    Since:
    September 11, 2008

    Modification History

    • Sep 11, 2008 (SDan McGee) Created.
    • Mar 26, 2009 (Marc Sernatinger) modified. Added sanitation of replacement strings.
    • Dec 12, 2012 (Don Hartman) modified. Added resolvePipelineTokens methods.

      • tokenPattern

        protected static java.util.regex.Pattern tokenPattern
        A non-greedy matcher looking for tokens similar to @{foo} and @{bar}. Created upfront so it can be shared since it never changes. This regex will return group(0) as "@{foo}" and group(1) as "foo" (the contents). Optionally injectible so pattern can be updated at runtime if necessary.

      • transformerPattern

        protected static java.util.regex.Pattern transformerPattern
        Pattern matching transformers, e.g. "SwitchTranformer~...". This regex will return group(0) as the whole string, group(1) as the transformer name, and group(2) as the rest (not including the tilde). Optionally injectible so pattern can be updated at runtime if necessary.

      • attributePattern

        protected static java.util.regex.Pattern attributePattern
        Pattern matching attributes and possible arguments, e.g. "omx_current_date|pattern=yyyy-MM-dd:sampleSecondArg=anotherValue". This regex will return group(0) as the whole string, group(1) as the attribute name, and group(2) as any arguments (excluding the first pipe). Optionally injectible so pattern can be updated at runtime if necessary.

      • jvmTokenPattern

        protected static java.util.regex.Pattern jvmTokenPattern
        A non-greedy matcher looking for tokens similar to ${foo} and ${bar}. This regex will return group(0) as "${foo}" and group(1) as "foo" (the contents). Optionally injectible so pattern can be updated at runtime if necessary.

      • jvmValuePattern

        protected static java.util.regex.Pattern jvmValuePattern
        Pattern matching JVM variables used in the current instance of OpenMigrate: "-Denv=HAMPDEN". This regex will return group(0) as the whole string and group(1) as the variable's value. Optionally injectible so pattern can be updated at runtime if necessary.

      • resolveTokens

        public static java.lang.String[] resolveTokens(MigrationNode node,
                                               java.lang.String original,
                                               TransformerFactory factory)
        Resolve tokens of the form @{object_name} and ${system_property} in the given string, substituting values of attributes from our MigrationNode and Java system properties. The tokens can also have arguments, which are documented in this classes' documentation.
        Parameters:
        node - the migration node to pull attribute values from
        original - the possibly token-filled value string
        factory - a transformer factory to locate our transformer beans when transformer tokens are found and parsed
        Returns:
        the value string with tokens substituted

      • resolveTokens

        public static java.lang.String[] resolveTokens(MigrationNode node,
                                               java.lang.String original)
        Resolve tokens of the form @{object_name} in the given string, substituting values of attributes from our MigrationNode. The tokens can also have arguments, which are documented in this classes' documentation. This method simply calls resolveTokens(MigrationNode, String, TransformerFactory) with a null factory parameter for convenience if no transformer factories are needed.
        Parameters:
        node - the migration node to pull attribute values from
        original - the possibly token-filled value string
        Returns:
        the value string with tokens substituted

      • resolvePipelineTokens

        public static java.lang.String[] resolvePipelineTokens(MigrationPipeline pipeline,
                                                       java.lang.String original,
                                                       java.lang.String batchRunNumberFormat)
        Resolve tokens of the form @{pipeline.batchId} in the given string, substituting values of pipeline and log attributes. The pipeline token resolver can take in 6 specific tokens: pipeline.batchId, pipeline.batchDate, pipeline.migrationLog.migratedCount, pipeline.migrationLog.ignoreCount, pipeline.migrationLog.failureCount, pipeline.migrationLog.abortedCount.
        Parameters:
        pipeline - the pipeline to pull attribute values from
        original - the possibly token-filled value string
        batchRunNumberFormat - SimpleDateFormat for the batchDate property (can be null)
        Returns:
        the value string with tokens substituted

      • resolvePipelineTokens

        public static java.lang.String[] resolvePipelineTokens(MigrationPipeline pipeline,
                                                       java.lang.String original)
        Resolve tokens of the form @{pipeline.batchId} in the given string, substituting values of pipeline and log attributes. The pipeline token resolver can take in 6 specific tokens: pipeline.batchId, pipeline.batchDate, pipeline.migrationLog.migratedCount, pipeline.migrationLog.ignoreCount, pipeline.migrationLog.failureCount, pipeline.migrationLog.abortedCount.
        Parameters:
        pipeline - the pipeline to pull attribute values from
        original - the possibly token-filled value string
        Returns:
        the value string with tokens substituted

      • resolveJvmTokens

        public static java.lang.String resolveJvmTokens(java.lang.String input)
        This method allows us to parse a given string, replacing any references to JVM variables such as ${env} with the value the JVM instance is using for this migration. JVM tokens must be referenced using the pattern ${jvmToken} for them to be properly resolved.
        Parameters:
        input - String that may contain JVM variables to replace.
        Returns:
        Resolved string whose JVM variable references have been replaced by their respective values.
